benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/catalog/plan - Retrieve plan for a given subscription and date

covered: Valid Request: Multiple success scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC13) cover retrieval with subscriptionId and/or requestedDate including boundary dates.
Empty Response / No Data: TC11 covers behavior when the DB contains no subscriptions/plans.
Query Parameters: Good coverage of parameter combinations and validation (TC01-TC08, TC14).
Error Handling: Negative cases for malformed params, non-existent subscription and combined-invalid inputs are covered (TC05, TC06, TC07, TC08).
Edge Conditions & Data Integrity: Overlap/conflict handling, boundary conditions and extra-parameter handling are present (TC12, TC13, TC14).
Security: Input-attack tests for SQL injection and XSS are included (TC17, TC18).
Performance & Concurrency: Response-time/performance under load and concurrent requests are included (TC15, TC16).
Regression & Compatibility: Regression test and backward compatibility scenario included (TC19, TC20).
gaps: Caching Behavior: No tests for caching headers or conditional GET behavior (ETag, If-None-Match, Cache-Control) — important for GET endpoints producing cacheable representations.
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests for API rate limiting, 429 responses or graceful degradation under throttling.

Response Headers and Content-Type: Tests assert "valid JSON Plan object" but there is no explicit assertion for required response headers (Content-Type: application/json) or other headers described in API contract.
Authorization granularity: 401 is tested (missing/invalid token) but there are no tests for authorization/permission failures (403) or role-based access scenarios.
Schema / Contract Validation: Tests check "valid JSON Plan object" but do not validate against an explicit Plan JSON schema (field-level checks, required fields, types, numeric/date formats).

Ambiguous expectations in some scenarios: TC03 and TC04 allow "200 or an appropriate default" which makes the acceptance criterion loose; the story expects returning the plan active for provided inputs — tests should pin expected behavior.

Pagination: Standard guideline includes pagination checks; while this endpoint returns a single Plan (so pagination is likely not applicable), there is no explicit note in tests asserting pagination is N/A for this endpoint.

Error status precision: Tests accept several possible status codes for some inputs (e.g., 400 or 422 for injection attempts, 409 or 500 for overlapping plans). The story/error section expects >=400 for invalid/missing resources — tests should verify precise, documented error codes.
recommendations: Add caching tests: assert presence and correctness of Cache-Control and ETag headers, and include conditional GET tests using If-None-Match to verify 304 handling where applicable.
Add rate-limiting tests: simulate rapid repeated requests to verify 429 responses or documented throttling behavior and graceful error payloads.
Validate response headers and content-type explicitly: ensure Content-Type: application/json and any other required headers are present and correct.
Add authorization/permission tests for forbidden cases: include scenarios that produce 403 when credentials are valid but lacking permission or using restricted client roles.
Introduce strict schema validation: add tests that validate the returned Plan object against the official Plan JSON schema (required fields, types, date formats, nested objects).
Tighten ambiguous scenarios: replace "200 or default" / multiple-possible-codes with precise expected outcomes aligned to API spec, or add separate tests to assert documented alternative behaviors.
Document pagination as N/A in the feature or add tests if API ever returns lists — include pagination tests only if endpoint supports list responses.

Make error-code expectations precise: decide (with API owners) whether invalid inputs map to 400 vs 422 and overlapping-plan conflicts map to 409 vs 500, then update tests to assert the chosen codes and error payload structure.
Add negative tests for malformed but well-formed-looking inputs (e.g., UUID with correct format but not matching pattern constraints) and for large/edge-case date ranges to catch date-parsing issues.
